newsitem.title: BULGARIA: BALKAN COUNTRIES PRESS AHEAD WITH TRANSPORT PROJECT.
newsitem.headline: BALKAN COUNTRIES PRESS AHEAD WITH TRANSPORT PROJECT.

text.p: Four countries are pressing ahead with plans to build a motorway and a railway through the Balkans linking the Black Sea with the Adriatic Sea, officials said on Friday.

Bulgaria's deputy foreign minister Stefan Tafrov told reporters the four countries agreed to speed projects for the construction and funding the link, called transport corridor number eight from Italy via Albania and Macedonia to Bulgaria.

"The meeting of the deputy foreign ministers from Bulgaria, Italy, Macedonia and Albania decided to speed up work for the realisation of corridor number eight and there is a clear political will for this," Tafrov said.
He said plans also included building optic communications links and an united energy system between the four countries.

Transport officials said corridor number eight would link Italy with Bulgaria's Black Sea ports of Bourgas and Varna via Plovdiv and Sofia in Bulgaria. From Sofia the road will pass through Skopje and Ohrid in Macedonia and would stretch to Duras in Albania.
The corridor will link Bourgas and Varna in Bulgaria with central Asia and the countries in the Caspian region, officials said.
Experts from the four countries will meet in September in Rome and the Italian side pledged to invite representatives of the international financial institutions at the meeting.
The transport ministers of the four counrties will meet in October in Skopje to sign a memorandum of understanding.
Tafrov said the project, which should attract private investors, was opened to other countries.
"We hope to start construction works before the end of the century," Tafrov said.
Bulgaria's deputy transport minister Kalcho Hinov said many foreign firms were showing interest in the project.
U.S. firm Bechtel is already working out a feasibility study of corridor number eight under another infrastructure initiative, Hinov said, adding that a heavy transport stream had been expected.
"The corridor is of a great importance for central Europe. Analysis prove that there is a new development of the world's market and especially for raw materials," Hinov said.
